qas.question: Which form of writing extended before the invention of paper?
What were the alphabets of Southeast Asia?
What other forms of writing materials were used during this period?
In what direction were the writings on a palm leaf?
The sections of the palm leafs were bound by what material?
Whose writing dates to the invention of paper?
When was invented in the 1st century?
What alphabets where domenent after the arrival of Europeans?
Who only used words that ended in consenants?
What direction was the writing on copper scrolls?

context: The antiquity of this form of writing extends before the invention of <b6_0>paper<b6_0/> around the year 100 in China. Note each <a0_0>palm leaf<a0_0/> section was only several lines, written <a3_0><b9_0>longitudinally<b9_0/><a3_0/> across the leaf, and bound by <a4_0>twine<a4_0/> to the other sections. The outer portion was decorated. The alphabets of <b5_0>Southeast Asia<b5_0/> tended to be <a1_0><b7_0>abugidas<b7_0/><a1_0/>, until the arrival of the <b8_0>Europeans<b8_0/>, who used words that also ended in consonants, not just vowels. Other forms of official documents, which did not use paper, included Javanese <a2_0>copperplate scrolls<a2_0/>. This material would have been more durable than paper in the tropical climate of Southeast Asia.
